diagrams.description: The history of operating systems began in the 1950s with batch processing systems that automated job sequences. The 1960s introduced multiprogramming and time-sharing (CTSS, Multics), enabling multiple users simultaneously. 1969 marked Unix's creation at Bell Labs. The 1970s saw microcomputer OSs emerge. 1981 brought MS-DOS for IBM PCs. 1984 introduced Macintosh with GUI. 1985 launched Windows 1.0. 1991 saw Linux's open-source debut. 2001 introduced macOS X with Unix foundations. 2007 revolutionized mobile OS with iOS, followed by 2008's Android. Modern developments continue with cloud-integrated and AI-enhanced operating systems.
diagrams.mermaid_code:
timeline
    title: The History of Operating Systems
    section: The 1950s - The First OS
        1956: GM-NAA I/O, the first operating system
    section: The 1960s - Multitasking and Timesharing
        1961: CTSS (Compatible Time-Sharing System)
        1964: IBM System/360
        1969: Unix is developed at Bell Labs
    section: The 1970s - The Rise of Personal Computers
        1973: CP/M (Control Program for Microcomputers)
        1977: Apple DOS
    section: The 1980s - The GUI Era
        1981: MS-DOS
        1984: Apple Macintosh System 1
        1985: Microsoft Windows 1.0
    section: The 1990s - The Open Source Revolution
        1991: Linux kernel is released
        1995: Windows 95
    section: The 2000s - The Mobile Era
        2001: Mac OS X
        2007: Apple iOS
        2008: Google Android
    section: The 2010s - The Cloud Era
        2010s: Rise of cloud-based operating systems
